radiographic_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation; right wrist with an 8-mm scapholunate gap; no degenerative osteoarthritis.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up examination 13.5 years later revealed mild intermittent pain, no new symptoms, and no clinical or radiographic deterioration.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation with wider separation on the right; modest right wrist osteoarthritis; no change in left wrist.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up 29 months later revealed pain and weakness bilaterally, more severe on the right; no worsening of condition.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Left scapholunate dissociation; no osteoarthritic changes noted.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Comparison radiographs 6 months later showed identical symmetric gap between scaphoid and lunate; symptoms unchanged at last follow-up.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation with no arthritic changes.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up 13 months later revealed only mild pain, no worsening overall.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation; no significant other injuries.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up examination 15 months later showed no symptoms and no clinical or radiographic deterioration.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation on clenched fist views; confirmed by arthrograms showing communication through scapholunate ligament.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Last follow-up 6 months later revealed mild wrist pain with twisting and lifting; no new symptoms.
